awd_titl_txt: CRI: CI-EN: Collaborative Research: mResearch: A platform for Reproducible and Extensible Mobile Sensor Big Data Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center of Excellence for Mobile Sensor Data-to-Knowledge (MD2K) has developed open-source software for smart phones and cloud. Scientists use MD2K software to develop and test algorithms to monitor health, wellness, and work productivity via wearable sensors. The mResearch project is aimed at assisting Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) researchers. The mResearch project will significantly enhance MD2K software and integrate Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices. The enhanced MD2K software will accelerate research in sensors design, mobile computing, privacy, analytics (especially machine learning and deep learning), and visualization. mResearch will enable CISE researchers to easily deploy their contributed software in scientific studies for health, smart homes, and workplace. The resulting discoveries and tools will help individuals improve their health, wellness, and work productivity.

MD2K has developed open-source mobile sensor big data software platforms mCerebrum for smartphones and Cerebral Cortex for the cloud. This scalable and generalizable infrastructure is used for collecting, analyzing, and sharing high-frequency, mobile sensor data and associated labels in the context of scientific field studies. In particular, it supports the development and validation of models and algorithms for inferring markers of health, wellness, and productivity, and their associated risk factors. It has already been used at eleven sites across the country to collect over 300 terabytes of mobile sensor data in the field setting from over 2,000 participants. It has resulted in new computational models for the detection of conversation, smoking, eating, craving, stress, and cocaine use. The mResearch project is making five significant infrastructure enhancements to the MD2K infrastructure to assist CISE researchers in mobile sensor development, mobile computing, privacy, analytics, visualization, and participant engagement. First, it will enable data analytic workflow management across multiple layers of the system to enable reproducible and extensible experimentation. Second, it will allow encapsulation of data sources to provide convenient and responsible access to them in data analytic workflows. Third, it will facilitate cloud-assisted complex, real-time analytics for personalizing mobile interventions and improving engagement. Fourth, simulators will be developed with the ability to feed stored data into the platform at various points to enable research on system components and properties such as data compression, transfer and storage, as well as the scalability of data analytics. Finally, Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices and services will be integrated. With these five enhancements, the MD2K software will provide a complete, open, and modularized architecture. It will include all aspects of sensor data collection, data processing algorithms, cloud-based machine learning, and IoT integration. The enhanced MD2K software will facilitate reproducible and extensible CISE research with high-frequency mobile sensor data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the mResearch project was to enable CISE researchers from across the country and around the world to easily conduct reproducible and extensible research on any aspect of the collection and analysis of high-frequency mobile sensor data.

The intellectual merit of the mResearch project included ten tools for collecting and processing high-frequency sensor data from wearables and two open-source high-frequency wearable sensor datasets. The tools included

1) a smartphone platform called mCerebrum, for the collection, processing, and real-time inference from high-frequency sensor data from the wearables and smartphones to generate real-time self-report and intervention prompts,

2) a companion big data cloud platform, called Cerebral Cortex, to receive sensor data from authenticated smartphone and smartwatch apps remotely from the field studies,

3) a wrist-worn wearable, called MotionSense HRV, with open source embedded sampling, signal processing, analytics, and AI algorithms with seven days of battery life for collecting and analyzing physiological and motion sensor data in field studies,

4) an open-source optimizing toolkit for smart ear-worn devices, called Auritus, for collecting, analyzing, and making AI inferences,

5) a deep-learning framework, called CardiacGen, for generating synthetic physiological data with statistically similar properties as real-life data for privacy-preserving training and testing of AI models,

6) a Python module, called mFlow, for specifying and executing machine learning (ML) workflows for reproducibility of ML experiments,

7) a high-level modeling language and compiler, called BayesLDM, for modeling complex multivariate time series data with missingness,

8) two imputation algorithms for handling missing data in high-frequency physiological sensor time series data called HeTVAE and PulseImpute,

9) a contact tracing app for Android called mContain to help local health agencies with contact tracing during the first stage of the COVID pandemic, and

10) a suite of smartwatch and smartphone apps called MOODS for tracking of momentary stress and stressors in real-life. 

The datasets released included 1) mOral, 1.5 billion sensor data points collected during 192 days of wrist-worn sensor wearing by 25 participants with fine-grained labels of micro-brushing and flossing activities to serve as a benchmark for AI models to detect brushing in real-life, and 2) PulseImpute, a transformation of PhysioNet dataset for training and testing of AI models for imputing pulsative signals such as physiological signals that include realistic missingness, baselines, and clinically-meaningful downstream tasks.

The mResearch Project led to many scientific advances in modeling, mobile and wearable systems, and privacy that were reported in six top-tier publications by the Memphis site. This included novel AI algorithms to show that sharing raw sensor data from wrist-worn inertial sensors can be used to reidentify the wearer with 94% accuracy, AI algorithms to detect the start and end times of brushing and flossing, and AI algorithms to detect the time spent on brushing each major teeth surface. These later capabilities bring the benefits of expensive electronic toothbrushes to users of regular toothbrushes.

The mResearch project had many broader impacts on the scientific community and society. The software, sensors, and tools were in 13 scientific studies on smoking, overeating, stress, heart failure, oral health, cocaine use, chronic pain and opioid usage, behavior change, and Workplace Performance. These studies include more than 2,500 users, collecting data for 106,80 person-days, resulting in 4.7 trillion data points that are leading to many scientific advances in health and wellness research with the potential to improve people’s lives. The mResearch project directly contributed to the training of 9 graduate students who received doctoral degrees and joined the workforce as scientists in both industry and academia, 4 software staff who went on to join the tech industry in senior positions, and the training of 156 scholars from 98 different institutions in multidisciplinary research via the annual mHealth Training Institutes. 42 webinars and 142 lecture videos were recorded that have been widely viewed over 46,000 times by users across nearly 22 countries.


Last Modified: 01/29/2024
Modified by: Santosh Kumar
